content.description: A decent route with nice movement. Expect pretty small holds in a variety of orientations. Decent rests can be found along the route. You'll find two cruxy sections: one near the bottom and one near the top.
content.location: One of the most southern starts on the west-facing wall. The route shares a start with The Monkey Sequence to the left of the big boulder leaning against the rock. Trend slightly right as The Monkey Sequence trends left after the first bolt.

content.description: A delicate slab leads to a slightly overhanging section of fun and powerful climbing. Keep your wits about you and subside the pump as you pull past the overhung portion and onto the last few feet of delicate vertical terrain.
content.location: First line just left of the ledge found on Full Blown Chaos

climbs.name: Phobos
climbs.fa: Bolted by Collin Wogenstahl FA Zeb Engberg

content.description:
Climb up to a crux at the 5th bolt.  This sequence felt as hard as V9 -- deliberate body position and power will help.  Continue through easier terrain to an interesting move at the last bolt.

While this route does have some glue, I found it to have better rock quality than its neighbors to the left.  The movement is both varied and excellent.
content.protection: 9 bolts.  In spring 2018, it was equipped with nice permadraws.
content.location: Begin just left of Power Path.  This is route 29 in the topo.

content.description: A mellow slab start with a high first bolt leads to a touchy move to grab a monster hollow flake. Scamper up to the base of a steeper headwall where the rock changes from grey to whitish. Fire this thin sustained section to surprisingly bad clipping holds for the ring anchors. Pumpy and fun despite a bit of a hollow feel
content.location: Located on the right side of the West facing wall. Walk past the routes in the big overhang and the dark alcove to the base of the vertical section of wall. The first 2 lines of bolts (which split at the 1st clip) are 12as, Kickback is the 3rd line with the high first bolt

content.description: Ooze up and right on a tricky slab with sharp holds past 4 bolts before tackling a fun arete feature with bigger holds. Very distinct flavors for both halves of the route. A good warm up.
content.location:
GTC is the last route on the right of the West facing formation, starting at the toe of the right arete and curving around to reach the edge of the formation.

Start 15-ish feet up the trail which follows the base of the cliff and climbs to the routes on the upper tier.

content.description: A solid slightly overhanging crux right off the ledge with good protection and plenty of crimps. you'll find the feet to be the most cryptic part of this route. It evens out after the flake into immaculate slab climbing on barely-there crimps and sharp footwork. Worth it if you don't mind cemented holds.
content.protection: Bolted, chains at the top with biners.
content.location: Clip the first bolt on the 5.10 to the left and then go right toward the right-facing flake. Follow the bolt line up.

content.description: Scamper up a bulgy section past a bolt to reach the ledge. Study the crack for a minute, fail to identify holds, and give it your best go anyway. The crack is very textured and sharp but essentially devoid of holds, making the 3rd clip a bit touchy. The right wall may hold the key to this sequence but the bolts are on the left of the crack, rendering the section capped by a large block a bit puzzling. Once you latch on to the block it's hero jug pulling to the top. Felt stout for 10b.
content.location: Just past the huge overhang you'll notice a recessed section of black rock with a ledge about 20' up. One bolt leads to this ledge from which two routes split. FBC goes left into the crack.
